hypothesis_content.title: Liquidation Cascade Amplification During Stress Regime Transitions
hypothesis_content.statement: During regime transitions from NEUTRAL to STRESS, large liquidation events (>$200M in 1 hour) act as amplifying catalysts, creating exaggerated price moves of 6-10% in the direction of initial move as forced liquidations trigger cascades.
hypothesis_content.rationale: During regime fragility, market microstructure becomes vulnerable to liquidity shocks. Large liquidations force additional position unwinds, creating self-reinforcing cascades. This amplification exceeds normal volatility during stable regimes.
entry_conditions: Regime transition signal: NEUTRAL to STRESS (regime confidence < 50%)
Price moves > 3% in direction of liquidations within that hour
Funding rate divergence exceeds 0.05% across major exchanges

exit_conditions.take_profit: Price move reaches +8% in trade direction OR volatility drops (1h ATR < 0.5%)

hypothesis_content.falsification_criteria: Large liquidations during stress transitions fail to produce >5% follow-through moves in >30% of cases.
